conclusion: Understand how the position and size of shadows change when the light source moves.
The shadow is cast by the object and is influenced by the position and intensity of the light source.
Object B is a baseball glove.
Object D is an ice cream sundae.
Shadow A is cast by the lampshade.
Shadow B is cast by the baseball glove.
Shadow C is cast by the cake.
Shadow D is cast by the ice cream sundae.
When the light source moves forward, it will be closer to the objects.
This will affect the angle at which the light hits the objects and the ground.
As the light source gets closer, the shadows will generally get larger because the angle of incidence will change.
The projection of the objects on the ground will be more elongated.
Shadow A will become larger and possibly more elongated as the light source gets closer and the angle of incidence changes.
Shadow B will also become larger and more elongated for the same reason.
Shadow C will become larger and more elongated.
Shadow D will become larger and more elongated.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will all become larger and more elongated when the light source moves forward.
